subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Report for each Iteration
msgSnippet: How is the merging different from file to file?  Is there any functional difference between merging xml1-xml2 and merging xml1-xml3?  If there is not a
messageBody:
How is the merging different from file to file? Is there any functional difference between merging xml1-xml2 and merging xml1-xml3? If there is not a functional difference, then I don't know that you need all the tests - you've obviously already ruled out any merges that start with xml2. If there is a functional difference (say the content of each xml object is in someway different), and you are testing the handling of those differences, then I would write a test for every variation that you are trying to handle.

That being said, you might be able to do it in a parameterized way, to save the effort of writing the permutations, but then I'm not sure how you document what you are trying to test,...I've never done the parameterized approach, but have heard it offered up a few times here.

my two cents,
good luck,
Dianne

-------------- Original message ----------------------
From: "Harshal Shah" <shahharshal@...>
> The question is more of implementation details but I was interested to know
> if there are API's or easy solution availables.
>
> Here's the problem:
>
> I have 3 xml files (xml1,xml2,xml3). I am testing the merging of these xml
> files. The following could be possible
>
> xml1-xml1
> xml1-xml2
> xml1-xml3
> xml3-xml1
> xml3-xml2
> xml3-xml3
>
> One method is to write testMethods for all these combination.
> One more approach is just write two for loops which will do this for
> me.Theproblem with this approach is the method is just single. Due to
> this, what
> is happening is the JUnit report just shows a single success or failure.
>
> I tried Anonymous Inner class approach but that did not work.
>
> Can somebody point me to some different approach to just have all the
> results displayed using just a single mehtod or some solution like this?
>
> -Thanks
>
> --
> http://shahharshal.blogspot.com/
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
